the men who will fill the gaps in the
faculty, a perfect string of appointments have been announced. Dr.
Edwin Greenlaw has been secured
as professor of English; Dr. Raymond Turner is named professor
of European History; Dr. Dean De
Witt Lewis will be professor of
Surgery; and Dr. Malone has been

only a question of a few

have an outlet in a "ladder" or
"round robin" contest in which
Johns Hopkins students will have
an opportunity to display their net
ability. The A. A. Board has given
its consent to this contest which will
decide which six men will represent
the university on the court this season. The opening of the tennis
competition awaits the time when
the outside courts will be ready for

The Blue Jay Orchestra
will make its second appearance in vaudeville at the Maryland Theatre during the week
of April 20-26. Immediately
following their first engagement, they were asked to return at an early date. The appearance of a college orchestra on the Keith circuit was
something unheard of before,
and the fact that they have
been asked to return proves
that they conducted themselves creditably in their
debut before the footlights.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 31. 1925
MR. RAMSBURG TALKS AT
FIRST ENGINEERING
LECTURE

TAILOR-MADE MAN
DROVERS & MECHANICS
NATIONAL BANK

He States That at Present Rate of Use
Petroleum Will Give Out
in 1938

"By 1938 there will be no petroleum in the United States, if the
present rate of consumption continues," said Mr. C. J. Ramsburg,
Vice-President of the Koppers
Company, Pittsburgh, at the first
engineering lecture of the season.
This means that the automotive industries must be dependent upon
benzol, a by-product of coke, when
the petroleum supply fails.
Mr. Ramsburg compared the
coal resources of this country and
the rest of the world by a map of
the United States on which all the
coal in the world was represented
as spread over the states east of the
Mississippi and Ohio Rivers and
north of .Maryland_to a depth.of six
feet. On this scale the coal resources of America is more than
equal to the amount of coal in other
countries.
The petroleum supply of the
United States,. however, when reduced to the power value of an
equal amount of -coat; covered an
area the size of Rhode Island on
the chart.
This deficiency of petroleum is
only one of the reasons why the
coke-producing industry is gaining
importance. Besides the value of
the coke and gas produced, there
are numerous by-products of the
industry. The chemical basic for
certain dyes and explosives; oils.
such as benzol and napthalene ; and
ammonia are a few of these products.
The next lecture of the series
will be given on Wednesday, April
.1. Mr. A. Hurlburt, Vice-President of the Equity Co., of Pittsburgh, will lecture on "The Distribution of Gas".

semester enters its

As the

and accurate book, three weeks will

hundred dollars in value.

EVANS RODGERS, '28

HOCHSCHILD,KOHN gc CO.

I. Evans Rodgers, universally
known on the campus as "Bill," was
the man who carried the Barnstormers' play through to success.
In the part of John Paul Bart, tailor's helper, "man of destiny," and
planner of "things Napoleon left
undone," his work was superb. He
entered his part whole-heartedly
and assumed the character of John
Paul with the same nonchalance and
ease with which the latter appropriated phrases, gestures, and ideas
as well as clothes. The suit, by the
way, really was not stolen, for he
won his bet. From the first, in some
indefinable way, he extended his
personality across the footlights,
and there, voila, is the secret of his
success.
Although "Bill" was by far the

The Blue Jay Orchestra
will make its second appearance in vaudeville at the Maryland Theatre during the week
of April 20-26. Immediately
following their first engagement, they were asked to return at an early date. The appearance of a college orchestra on the Keith circuit was
something unheard of before,
and the fact that they have
been asked to return proves
that they conducted themselves creditably in their
debut before the footlights.

MR. RAMSBURG TALKS AT
FIRST ENGINEERING
LECTURE

TAILOR-MADE MAN
DROVERS & MECHANICS
NATIONAL BANK

He States That at Present Rate of Use
Petroleum Will Give Out
in 1938

"By 1938 there will be no petroleum in the United States, if the
present rate of consumption continues," said Mr. C. J. Ramsburg,
Vice-President of the Koppers
Company, Pittsburgh, at the first
engineering lecture of the season.
This means that the automotive industries must be dependent upon
benzol, a by-product of coke, when
the petroleum supply fails.
Mr. Ramsburg compared the
coal resources of this country and
the rest of the world by a map of
the United States on which all the
coal in the world was represented
as spread over the states east of the
Mississippi and Ohio Rivers and
north of .Maryland_to a depth.of six
feet. On this scale the coal resources of America is more than
equal to the amount of coal in other
countries.
The petroleum supply of the
United States,. however, when reduced to the power value of an
equal amount of -coat; covered an
area the size of Rhode Island on
the chart.
This deficiency of petroleum is
only one of the reasons why the
coke-producing industry is gaining
importance. Besides the value of
the coke and gas produced, there
are numerous by-products of the
industry. The chemical basic for
certain dyes and explosives; oils.
such as benzol and napthalene ; and
ammonia are a few of these products.
The next lecture of the series
will be given on Wednesday, April
.1. Mr. A. Hurlburt, Vice-President of the Equity Co., of Pittsburgh, will lecture on "The Distribution of Gas".

won his bet. From the first, in some
indefinable way, he extended his
personality across the footlights,
and there, voila, is the secret of his
success.
